Thanks, Jeff.
Our next question is from Cherilyn Radbourne with Scotia Capital. Please go ahead with your question.
Thanks very much, and good morning. We are running long. So I'm just going to ask one.

And that is, with regards to the STB Reauthorization Bill, can you just comment on the committee's level of openness to continue to work with you on the bill? Because my sense was that the original posturing was, they wanted to settle all of those issues before the bill was actually released. And their thinking was that, once it was released, there would not be material changes.
No, I don't think that's ultimately how it came out. Again, it's a very complex bill. They are very open to discussion. We're continuing discussions today. They're talking with really both sides.

And one of the things I've seen with the committee – they want to get it right. Again, it – the members that we talk to are scared to death that they get this wrong, because we've made it very clear. We don't – we have very little room – there is no room to move. And if they get it wrong, investment and good jobs go the wrong way. And that is the last thing you want in today's environment.
And with the healthcare bill debate sort of dragging on, and the prospect of mid-term elections, what do you think the risk is that this gets deferred again?
I'm not quite sure I know how to call that one. I mean, obviously, what happened in Massachusetts says most people don't want more government oversight.

And I look at our industry – we're the only industry, when you look at it in terms of transportation infrastructure in this country, that we kept our word. As profits moved up and returns moved up substantial new capacity went in. And it's a pretty hard argument to debate, because those are the facts. So we'll see what happens.
Okay. Thanks very much. That's all from me.
Okay, Cherilyn.
Our next question is from the line of Scott Plower from Macquarie Bank Please go ahead with your question, sir.
Yeah, good morning, all.
Good morning, Scott.

Just a couple of quick questions. A couple for Jack. You mentioned that Ag and Industrial, a little bit more tariff based. What proportion of those businesses lines roughly are for tariff versus contractual?

I would say that the industrial products business, Scott, is primarily tariff-based. And I would say the Ag product world, the Ag, my Ag products world is a little unique in that some of my contracts take their pricing from tariffs. So it's kind of a mixed bag in there. So tariffs do have more of an influence both on the contractual side as well as the tariffs side.

Okay. And then what proportion of your auto business is the legacy renewal this year? In other words, is it a third of the auto business that you currently have, I'm just trying to get a sense on revenues, just to get the common sizing of just the legacy renewal, relative to your auto business in total?
I would say, roughly it's in the 25, 30%.

Okay. And then just one quick question for Dennis. Is the velocity number that you showed us on, I forget the exact page, is that mix adjusted, in other words, obviously everything fell off in terms of volumes, but some of the intermodal fell off less than some of the slower moving bulk trains or manifest trains. Is that a mix adjusted number?
It's an absolute number. Whatever it is, it is Scott.
Okay. So there was some benefit from mix then because you had relatively lesser falloff in the intermodal versus some of the other businesses?
Yeah, there will be a small amount of mix in there, you bet.
Okay, good. Well, thanks very much.
Thanks, Scott.
Thank you. Our last question will be from the line of Jason Seidl with Dahlman Rose. Please go ahead with your question, sir.

Hey, everyone. Listen, Jim I think you've mentioned that you guys might pull back some of the capital spend. Could you talk about some of the areas you might reduce capital spending if this bill goes on as is?

Well, you've to ask yourself the question of what's the viability of growth in the returns. If you look at our – Rob gave you the number. We've got 2.5 billion kind of targeted; I still need the Board to approve where we're going there, which includes 200 million of positive train control. So leaves you 2.3. You look at the 2.3, you've got about 3 to $400 million of growth capital in there. And what we will do is, take a very hard look at the returns of where we thought we would be, we're not there yet. That's the thing I keep reminding members of Congress. While we've had a nice run in our profitability, in our returns, we still, in my mind are a long ways away from justifying kind of new capital. So we take a hard look at it, and our capacity, our facilities, new locomotive acquisitions, all that comes into play.

Okay, that's good color. Last question on the coal – on the stockpiles. Given the normal seasonal weather pattern, how long does it take to start drawing down the day supply among the utilities that you guys supply?

Jason, I think we are actually in kind of a draw down now because of the extreme weather situations. So that's good. There is a lot of things that are going to enter into it. It's going to be – some plants will take some sort of maintenance shutdowns here until the spring leading up to the summer burn. I guess we're probably in a situation where you have some discussion as to weather. Typically what would happen is if they had stockpiled a little bit to get there, this year they probably won't do that. So that will probably help to some extent, and then whatever is going to go on with industrial production, the steel utilization is at 65% versus last year at 45%. If that stays true, if U.S. Steel brings up their, I think it's long view is the one they are talking about bringing up, all of those things consume electricity. That industrial production will help us as well. So it's really a myriad of different things that will help us.
Fair enough. Guys, I appreciate the time as always.
Thanks, Jason.
Thank you. There are no further questions at this time. I would like to turn the floor back over to Mr. Jim Young for closing comments.
Well, I thank everyone, for joining us this morning. I look forward to talking to you again in three months. Have a good day.
This concludes today's teleconference. You may disconnect your lines at this time. Thank you for your participation.
